title: Physics Chapter Notes
description: Board Notes. Keep in mind vector symbols aren't shown. Many example problems aren't shown either.

title: Chapter 1 Notes
description:
• Science is a way of figuring out the world around us
  • Empiricism - knowledge only by observation, no innate form
  • David Hew - adopted this idea, developed peer review
  • Began in 17th and 18th centuries, built upon itself
  • Chemistry
    • The science that describes matter
    • Most basically thought of in particles & reactions with each other
    • Physical and chemical changes
    • Energy releases through reactions
  • Chemical vs Physical
    • Reactions
      • Chemical - composition changes, matter reconfigured
      • Physical - composition stays the same, matter stays the same
    • Properties
      • Chemical - observed only through chemical reaction, composition changes
      • Physical - observed while nothing changes
  • Classification of Matter
    • Matter
      • Mixtures
        • Homogeneous - evenly mixed
        • Heterogeneous - unevenly mixed
      • Pure substances
        • Elements - atom, most basic form
        • Compounds - atoms bonded to one another
  • Determining Empirical Formulas of organic (carbon-based) compounds
    • Combustion analysis
      • Employs a combustion train
      • X + O2 -> CO2 + H2O
      • Steps
        • Find moles C
        • Find moles H
        • Use law of conservation of mass to find mass of O in x
        • Find moles O
        • Divide by minimum moles to get coefficients
      • n = molecular mass / empirical mass
    • Percentage mass -> moles -> coefficients
  • Hydrates
    • An ionic solid with a specific stoichiometric ratio of water molecules trapped in the crystal lattice
    • Written with dot: CuSO4 * 5 H2O

title: Chapter 3 Notes
description:
• Solution concentration
    • Solvent - the component present in the largest amount
    • Solute(s) - the other component(s)
    • Molarity M = mol solute / L solution
    • % by mass = mass solute / mass solution * 100%
    • Specific gravity = density / density of water
    • Dilution
      • Adding solvent to solution
      • Moles solute initial = moles solute final = M1V1 = M2V2

title: Chapter 5 Notes
description:
• The Periodic Law - the properties of the elements are periodic functions of their atomic numbers
  • Periodicity - Periodic trends
    • Atomic size
      • 1/2 the internuclear distance between two atoms with the same nuclei (i.e. in homonuclear diatomic molecules or a crystal lattice of the element)
      • Trend - bigger going down and left
      • Explanation
        • Atoms of the elements grow larger as we descent a family because the outermost electron is in an orbital in a higher shell which means the orbital is larger, so the atom is larger
        • Atoms grow smaller as we move to the right across the period because the added electron is placed in the same shell (~same size orbital) so that the Z eff increases
      • Z eff = effective nuclear charge - the portion of the nuclear charge which and individual electron actually experiences
      • Z = atomic number = number of protons
      • Shielding - the partial cancellation of positive charge caused by inner electrons (electrons closer to the nucleus)
      • Electrons in the same shell do not shield each other very effectively
    • Ionic size
      • Positively charged ions (cations) are always smaller than the neutral parent (usually ~1/2 as large)
      • When an electron or electrons are removed the particle always shrinks
      • Negatively charged ions (anions) are always larger than the neutral parent (usually ~2x as large)
      • When an electron or electrons are added the particle always grows
      • After ion formation the family trend is again downward
      • Isoelectronic species
        • Same number of electrons
        • Size decreases as Z increases
    • Ionization energy
      • The amount of energy required to remove the highest electron from a mole of gas phase atoms or ions
      • Trend
        • IE increases up and to the right
        • Successive IE's always increase
        • A very large change in a successive IE indicates removal of an electron from an inner shell (all valence electrons removed)
      • Explanations
        • IE decreases as we descend a family because the outermost electron is in a higher shell which implies a higher potential energy and the effective nuclear charge it "feels" is remaining constant so less energy is required to boost it off the atom
        • IE increases as we move to the right across the period because the outermost electron is added to the same shell and "feels" a larger effective nuclear charge so is more tightly drawn to the nucleus
    • Metallic character
    • Electronegativity
      • The tendency of an atom to attract bonding electron (i.e. electron(s) from a different atom)
      • Trend - up and to the right
    • Electron affinity
      • The energy change when 1 mole of gas phase atoms of an element gain an electron to form a negative ion
      • The atoms of many elements will not gain an electron in this way and are considered to have an EA of zero
      • Trend - up and to the right, no nobles
      • Lots of exceptions to this trend
  • Photon-electron spectroscopy
    • Hit electrons in atoms with high-power light
    • Measure KE of electrons coming off
    • Derive binding energy

title: Chapter 4 Notes
description:
• Structure of atoms
    • Dalton's model - cathode-ray tube experiments
    • Plum-pudding model - Rutherford and the gold foil experiments
    • Nuclear model - Millikan's oil drop
    • Fundamental particles
  • Atomic mass = ((abundance isotope 1)*(mass isotope 1)+(abundance isotope 2)*(mass isotope 2)+...(abundance isotope n)*(mass isotope n))/100
  • Electromagnetic Radiation
    • Light behaves as a wave
    • Wavelength = lambda
    • Frequency = nu
    • c = lambda*nu
    • c = 2.99292456 * 10^8 m/s = 2.998 * 10^8 m/s
    • E = h*nu
    • h = 6.626 * 10^-34 J*s
    • E = energy of 1 photon of that radiation
  • Bohr Model
    • Rydberg equation - 1/lambda = R(1/n1^2 - 1/n2^2)
      • n1 / n2 positive integers
      • n2 > n1
    • Principles (based on Hydrogen)
      • Electron exists in fixed, specific (quantized) energy levels
      • Electron orbits the nucleus in circular path of fixed radius
      • Larger orbits correspond to higher energy levels
      • Electron can absorb energy and jump to a higher level (large orbit) but will immediately drop down in energy to a lower orbit by emitting a photon
    • En = -1/n^2 * (h^2 / 8*pi^2*m*a0^2) = -2.18*10^18 J / n^2
    • /\ E = Ef - Ei
  • Electronic Structure
    • Quantum numbers
    • Orbital diagrams
    • Electronic configurations
    • Noble gas shorthand

title: Chapter 7 Notes
description:
• Two classes of compounds
    • Ionic
      • High melting points
      • All solids at room temperature
      • Liquid conducts electricity
      • Usually metal and non-metal
    • Covalent
      • Low melting points
      • Most liquids or gases at room temperature
      • Liquid doesn't conduct electricity
      • Usually all non-metals
  • Bonding
    • Ionic - transfer of 1 or more electrons forming oppositely charged ions
    • Covalent - sharing of pairs of electrons
    • Valence electrons are involved in forming these bonds - outermost shell, highest principal energy level, highest quantum n value
  • Lewis dot structures
    • Atoms / monatomic ions
      • Follow Hund's rule for filling
      • Maximum of 8 valence electrons
      • Only exist in s and p subshells
      • Ions require brackets on outside and charge
    • Ionic bonding
      • Formation of ions
        • Anions - electrons are added in the normal aufbau order
        • Cations - electrons are removed from the valence shell first (not necessarily reverse aufbau)
      • Lewis dot representations
        • Don't display dots on ions that drop highest shell
        • No brackets on ions without dots
        • Brackets on ions with dots
      • Strength of ionic attractions
        • Coulomb's law
          • F is directly proportional to (q1 * q2)/r^2
          • F is force of attraction
          • q1, q2 represent the magnitude of charge
          • r is the radial distance between centers of charge
          • Key ideas
            • Force increases as the product of the charge magnitudes
            • Force decreases as the ions get larger (greater distance between the centers)
          • Charge density = amount of charge / volume of the particle - as charge density increases, F increases
  • Lewis structures
  • Useful guidelines
    • Formal charge
      • Tool for evaluating Lewis structures (i.e. is the Lewis structure displaying an extreme redistribution of electrons?)
      • It is not a true charge
      • Rules
        • The sum of formal charges on the atoms in a molecule or ion must add to the charge of that particle
        • FC = group # - (# bonds + # non-bonding electrons) = # valence electrons - # electrons displayed in Lewis structure assuming equal sharing of electrons
      • Interpretation of FC
        • Smaller FCs are better
        • If non-zero FCs occur, more highly electronegative atoms should be more negative in FC
        • Adjacent FCs of the same sign are very bad (repel each other)
  • Covalent bonding
    • Sharing of pairs of valence electrons between non-metal atoms
    • The attractive force of covalent bonding
    • Sharing
      • Differences in electronegativity (/\ EN) can be used to quantify how equal or unequal is the sharing between bonded atoms
      • If /\ EN = 0 or very small, pure covalent (non-polar bond, no new charge)
      • If /\ EN is quite large (>1.9), ionic bond (full charges of opposite sign)
      • If /\ EN is intermediate, polar covalent bond (partial charges on the bonding ions)
    • Dipole - equal and opposite charges at a fixed distance
    • Dipole moment - mu = q x d
    • Ionic character - 100*mu real/mu theoretical
  • Exceptions to octet rule in order of increasing number of molecules that display this
    • Molecules with an odd number of electrons
      • NO, NO2
      • Tend to dimerize - two react to form double coefficient molecule
    • Molecules in which the central atom has fewer than 8 valence
      • Central element is Be or B
      • Incomplete octet
    • Molecules/ions in which the central atom has more than 8 electrons around it
      • PCl5, SF6
      • Expanded octet
      • Central atom must be from the third period or below

title: Chapter 2 Notes
description:
• Ionic compounds
    • Composed of positive ions (cations) and negative ions (anions) in a fixed ratio producing a neutral compound
    • Monatomic ions: Cl-, F-, S-2
    • Polyatomic ions: CO3-2, NO2-, list of 13
    • Name in same order - CaCl2 = calcium chloride
    • Any metal, and any nonmetal, when heated up, will form an ionic compound
      • sodium reacts with oxygen -> Na2O
      • aluminum reacts with nitrogen -> AlN
      • titanium reacts with sulfur -> TiS2, Ti2S3
  • Avogadro's number
    • 6.022045*10^23
    • A mole of x is Avogadro's number of atoms, molecules, or formula units
  • Molar mass - the mass in grams of 1 mole of a substance
  • Formulas
    • Types
      • Simplest or empirical formula - specifies the simplest whole number ratio among the components
      • Molecular formula - specifies the number of atoms of each type in a molecule or the substance
      • Structural formula - displays the bonding pattern among the atoms in a molecule
    • % composition data -> empirical formula

title: Chapter 6 Notes
description:
• Types of Chemical Reactions
    • Reactions in aqueous solutions
      • Acid / base reactions
      • Precipitation reactions
      • Oxidation reduction reactions
    • Electrolytes - substances whose aqueous solution conducts electricity
      • Types
        1. Soluble ionic compounds
          • Ex: NaCl
          • Always strong
          • NaCl (s) -H2O> Na+ (aq) + Cl- (aq)
          • Dissociation reaction - ions separate
        2. Acids
          • Can be strong or weak
          • Ex: H2SO4
            • H2SO4 -H2O> H+ (aq) + HSO4- (aq)
            • HSO4 (aq) <H2O> H+ (aq) + SO4-2 (aq)
          • Ex: HC2H3O2 - HC2H3O2 (aq) <H2O> H+ (aq) + C2H3O2- (aq)
          • Ionization reaction - ions are created
        3. Bases
          • Can be strong or weak
            • Strong bases - soluble ionic hydroxides
              • NaOH
              • LiOH
              • KOH
              • RbOH
              • CsOH
              • Ca(OH)2
              • Sr(OH)2
              • Ba(OH)2
            • Weak bases - molecular substances (Ex: NH3)
      • Strong conducts well and ionizes completely, weak conducts poorly and ionizes only partially
    • Memorize strong acids
      • HCl (aq) - hydrochloric acid
      • HBr (aq) - hydrobromic acid
      • HI (aq) - hydroiodic acid
      • HNO3 (aq) - nitric acid
      • H2SO4 (aq) - sulfuric acid
      • HClO4 (aq) - perchloric
  • Different Forms of Chemical Equations
    • Formula unit
      • All reactants and products are specified by full formulas
      • Compounds by molecular or formula unit forms
      • No ions indicated
      • Ex: 2HCl + Ca(OH)2 -> CaCl2 + 2H2O
    • Total ionic
      • All strong electrolytes are displayed as separated into ions
      • All weak electrolytes are displayed as formula units
      • Ex: 2H+ + 2Cl- + Ca+2 + 2OH- -> Ca+2 + 2Cl- + 2H2O
    • Net ionic
      • Any ions which are displayed on both sides of the total ionic are dropped out
      • Coefficients are simplified
      • Ex: H+ + OH- -> H2O
  • Solubility of ionic compounds
    • Soluble - >.02 M dissolve
    • Insoluble - <.02 M dissolve
    • General Rules
      1. All alkali metal salts and salts of NH4+ are soluble
      2. All salts of NO3-, CH3COO- (acetate), ClO3- (chlorate), and ClO4- (perchlorate) are soluble
      3. The salts of Cl-, Br-, I-, and F- (halogen salts) are mostly soluble with a few exceptions (Ag, Hg, Pb)
      4. Most salts of OH-, CO3-2, and PO4-3 are insoluble
  • Redox reactions
    • Redox = oxidation-reduction
    • Oxidation - loss of electrons
    • Reduction - the gain of electrons
    • Oxidizing agent gets reduced
    • Reducing agent gets oxidized
    • Oxidation numbers
      • A formal system for keeping track of electrons
      • Assigned to individual atom or ion
      • Rules
        1. The sum of the oxidation number of all the atoms in a particle must add to the charge on the particle
        2. F is always -1 in all compounds
        3. O is almost always -2 in all compounds
        4. H is positive with a nonmetal and negative with a metal
        5. Elements in a family usually are assigned oxidation numbers that match the ion charge
    • In all redox reactions, there must be a change in oxidation numbers

title: Chapter 8 Notes
description:
• Molecular structure and covalent bond theories
    • VSEPR - Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion
      • The shapes of molecules (the angles between the various bonds in a molecule) can be predicted by focusing on each central atom and determining the number of regions around it which contain valence electrons, either lone pairs or bonding regions, and placing them at the greatest separation due to mutual repulsions
      • Goal: determine bond angles / molecular geometry

ExampleBonding RegionsLone PairsElectronic RegionsElectronic GeometryBond AnglesMolecular Geometry
PCl5505trigonal bipyramidal90, 120, 180trigonal bipyramidal
SF4415trigonal bipyramidal<90, <120, <180seesaw
IF3325trigonal bipyramidal<90, <180T-shaped
XeF2235trigonal bipyramidal180linear
SF6606octahedral90, 180octahedral
IF5516octahedral<90, <180square pyramidal
XeF4426octahedral90, 180square planar
  • Trigonal bipyramidal
    • Atoms at sides - equatorial
    • Atoms at top and bottom - axial
  • Valence bond theory
    • Problem: "sharing" means overlap of orbitals but the atomic orbitals on isolated atoms are not oriented in space at the proper angles
    • Two hypotheses
      1. Valence bond theory - the atomic orbitals hybridize to create new atomic orbitals at the appropriate angles
      2. Molecular orbital theory - new orbitals encompassing multiple nuclei (molecular orbitals) are created
    • Hybridization
      • Adding the electron wave functions
      • The new hybrid orbitals are designated by a notation which shows the subshells of the orbitals and how many of each were mixed
        • 2 orbitals mixed: s + p -> s p
        • 3 orbitals mixed: s + 2 p's -> s p^2
        • 4 orbitals mixed: s + 3 p's -> s p^3
        • 5 orbitals mixed: s + 3 p's + d -> s p^3 d
        • 5 orbitals mixed: s + 3 p's + 2 d's -> s p^3 d^2
      • Principles
        1. The number of hybrid orbitals created matches the number electron regions
        2. Hybridization is (usually) used only on central atoms
      • Steps in hybridization - totally theoretical
        1. Promotion of electrons to create half-filled orbitals
        2. Hybridization of these orbitals
  • Multiple bonds
    • Sigma bonds - involve end-to-end overlap of atomic orbitals producing a region of electron density which is cylindrically symmetrical about the internuclear axis
    • Pi bonds - involve side-to-side overlap of p orbitals producing regions of electron density which are different at different angles
    • Rules
      • The first bond between any two atoms is always sigma
      • Past the first, every other bonds are pi
    • A valence bond description of a molecule identifies the atomic orbitals which are overlapping for each bond in the molecule

title: Chapter 10 Notes
description:
• Acids and Bases
    • Three theories used in Chemistry
      1. Svante Arrhenius - 1814
        • An acid is a substance which produces H+ ions when added to water
        • A base is a substance which produces OH- ions when added to water
      2. Brønsted-Lowry
        • Acid - proton donor
        • Base - proton acceptor
        • An acid/base reaction is  a proton transfer reaction
      3. Lewis
    • Conjugate acid/base pairs - species which differ by a proton (H+)
    • Autoionization - automatic ionization

Acids
Bases
Taste sour
Taste bitter
Neutralize bases
Neutralize acids
React with metals
React with organics
Changes color of acid/base indicators
Changes color of acid/base indicators
  • Strengths of Acids
    • Acid X is stronger than acid Y means that X is ionized to a greater extent or means that X has a greater tendency to donate a proton
    • Two types of acid strength issues to know
      1. Binary acids HX or HA
        • As the H-X bond grows stronger, HX becomes a weaker acid (Ex: HF < HCl < HBr < HI)
        • As the X grows larger, there is less effective overlap with the 1s on the H, which implies a weaker bond
      2. Ternary acids
        • The donatable proton is always bonded to an O
        • The more O's attached to the central X, the weaker the OH bond (Ex: HNO3 > HNO2)
        • For ternary aids with the same number of O's, as X increases in EN, the acid gets stronger (Ex: H2SeO4 < H2SO4)

title: Chapter 11 Notes
description:
• Calculations involving Acid/Base and Redox Reactions
    • Molarity (M) - mol solute / L solution
    • Dilution
      • To dilute a solution means to add solvent
      • This lowers the molarity but does not change the # of moles of solute present
      • M1V1 = M2V2
  • Acid/Base neutralization reactions
    • Ex: HCl + NH3 -> NH4Cl
    • Limiting reactant problems
    • Percent by mass
  • Titration
    • Volumetric technique for analysis of reacting solutions
    • Terminology
      1. The titrant is the solution in the buret
      2. If the solution has a known concentration it is called a standard
      3. Titrant is slowly added to a second solution that it reacts with
      4. When the amount of added titrant completely reacts with the species in the second solution, we have reached the equivalence point
      5. Hopefully when the equivalence point is reached the indicator in the second solution will change color (this is the end point)
  • KHP - potassium hydrogen phthalate
  • Balancing Redox Equations
    • Learning procedures for producing a balanced net ionic equation for redox reactions occurring in acidic or basic aqueous solutions
    • Two methods
      1. Oxidation number method
        • Procedure
          1. Eliminate H+ and H2O if included
          2. Balance the non-H/O elements
          3. Assign oxidation numbers
          4. Balance electrons lost/gained
          5. Balance the O by adding water
          6. Balance the H by adding H+
          7. If basic, add OH- to both sides to convert all H+ to H2O
          8. Check to make sure charge balances
        • Ex: C2H4 + MnO4- + H+  -->  CO2 + Mn+2 + H2O
          1. C2H4 + MnO4-  -->  CO2 + Mn+2
          2. C2H4 + MnO4-  -->  2CO2 + Mn+2
          3. C(-2)2H4 + Mn(+7)O4-  -->  2C(+4)O2 + Mn(+2)+2
          4. 5C2H4 + 12MnO4-  -->  10CO2 + 12Mn+2
          5. 5C2H4 + 12MnO4-  -->  10CO2 + 12Mn+2 + 28H2O
          6. 5C2H4 + 12MnO4- + 36H+  -->  10CO2 + 12Mn+2 + 28H2O
          7. +24  -->  +24
      2. Half-reactions method
        • Procedure
          1. Eliminate H+ and H2O if included
          2. Divide into 2 half-reactions (oxidation step and reduction step)
          3. Balance the non-H/O elements by inspection
          4. Balance the O by adding water on the other side
          5. Balance the H by adding H+ on the other side
          6. If basic solution, add OH- to both sides to convert all H+ to H2O
          7. Balance the charge by adding electrons to the more positive side (Electrons must be added to opposite sides of the half-reactions)
          8. Multiply the half-reactions to cancel the e- and add half-reactions together
          9. Cancel species common to both sides
        • Ex: C2H4 + MnO4- + H+  -->  CO2 + Mn+2 + H2O
          1. C2H4 + MnO4-  -->  CO2 + Mn+2
          2. C2H4  -->  CO2   &&   MnO4-  -->  Mn+2 
          3. C2H4  -->  2CO2   &&   MnO4-  -->  Mn+2
          4. 4H2O + C2H4  -->  2CO2   &&   MnO4-  -->  Mn+2 + 4H2O
          5. 4H2O + C2H4  -->  2CO2 + 12H+   &&   8H+ + MnO4-  -->  Mn+2 + 4H2O
          6. Not basic
          7. 4H2O + C2H4  -->  2CO2 + 12H+ + 12e-   &&   5e- + 8H+ + MnO4-  -->  Mn+2 + 4H2O
          8. 20H2O + 5C2H4 + 60e- + 96H+ + 12MnO4-  -->  10CO2 + 60H+ + 60e- + 12Mn+2 + 48H2O
          9. 5C2H4 + 12MnO4- + 36H+   -->  10CO2 + 12Mn+2 + 48H2O
  • Redox Titrations
    • Two key differences related to acid/base titrations
      1. Reacting ratios are more complex - use the balanced redox reaction
      2. Indicators are much less prevalent - the workhorse of redox titrations is KMnO4
        • MnO4- -> Mn+2 (in an acid) or -> MnO2 (in a base)

title: Chapter 14 Notes
description:
• Solutions
    • Solution - homogeneous mixture of 2 or more pure substances
    • Solvent - the substance present in the largest amount
    • Solute(s) - the other substances
    • Dissolution - dissolving
    • Energy considerations
      • Two driving forces in nature
        • The movement to lower energy
        • The movement toward disorder (always)
  • General case
    • In order for A to dissolve into B
      1. A particles must be separated
      2. B particles must be separated
      3. A and B particles come together
    • Heat of solution - 1+2+3
    • Heat of solvation - 2+3
    • "like dissolves like"
      • Substances held together by similar forces of attraction will dissolve into each other well
      • Polar and ionic solutes will dissolve into polar solvents (H2O)
      • Non-polar solutes will dissolve into non-polar solvents
    • Crystal lattice energy
      • The energy released in the process of forming one mole of any ionic compound from its constituent ions in the gas phase
      • M+ (g) + X- (g) -> MX (s) + energy
      • As the charge density (amount of charge per unit volume) of the ions goes up, the crystal lattice energy increases
      • As the crystal lattice energy increases, the hydration energy increases
    • As charge density increases, solubility in H2O decreases
  • Factors affecting solubility
    • Solubility is quantified by the concentration of a saturated solution of that substance
    • Factors
      1. Nature of the solute/solvent (i.e. like dissolves like)
      2. Temperature
        • For solids and liquids, as temperature increases, solubility increases
        • For gases, as temperature increases, solubility decreases

title: Chapter 13 Notes
description:
• Liquids and Solids
    • Intermolecular Forces (IMFs)
      • Intra = within - covalent bonds (or ionic bonds)
      • Types
        • Dispersion
          • Occurs between all types of particles
          • 1/d^7 force
          • Other names
            • London Forces
            • van der Waals
            • Induced dipole-induced dipole
          • As the electron cloud of a particle (atom, molecule, ion) gets larger and/or contains more negative charge
          • We say it is more "polarizable" and this leads to larger dispersion forces
        • Dipole-dipole
          • Occurs between only polar molecules
          • 1/d^4 force
          • As the dipole moment of the molecule increases, the dipole-dipole attraction increases
        • H-bonding
          • Only between molecules in which a N, O, or F is bonded to a H
          • Positive hydrogen attracted to other molecule's negative lone pairs
        • Ion-ion attractions (disputed)
          • F is proportional to q1*q2/d^2
          • As ion size increases, force decreases
          • As ion charge increases, force increases
  • Liquids
    • Characteristic properties
      • Viscosity
        • Resistance to flow
        • Viscometer - device for measurement
        • Unit - poise
        • As IMFs increase, viscosity increases
      • Surface tension
        • Tendency to minimize surface area
        • As IMFs increase, surface tension increases
      • Evaporation
        • Liquid to gas blow the boiling point
        • Occurs at surface of all liquids at all temperatures
        • To escape must
          • be at surface - surface area is directly proportional to the rate of evaporation
          • have sufficient KE to overcome IMFs - as temperature increases, the rate of evaporation increases
      • Vapor Pressure
        • Equilibrium
        • When rate of evaporation = rate of condensation
        • No further change in the amount of vapor
      • Boiling
        • The formation of bubbles in the body of a liquid that contain the gas phase of the liquid
        • When the vapor pressure of the liquid is at least as large as the external pressure on the liquid, bubbles can form
        • The boiling point of any liquid is the temperature at which its vapor pressure equals the external pressure
        • Normal boiling point is the temperature at which a liquid's vapor pressure is 1 atmosphere
        • As IMFs increase, normal boiling point increases
  • Energy of Phase Changes
    • Heating Curves
    • Warming
      • Steps 1, 3, 5
      • q = m*c*/\T
      • c = specific heat of that phase
    • Melting
      • Step 2
      • q = n*/\H fus
      • q = m*/\H fus
      • /\H fus
        • Heat of fusion
        • The amount of heat required to convert 1 mol or 1 g of the solid phase into liquid at the melting point
        • 6.02 kJ/mol or 334 J/g for H2O
    • Boiling
      • Step 4
      • q = n*/\H vap
      • q = m*/\H vap
      • /\H vap
        • Heat of vaporization
        • The amount of heat required to convert 1 mol or 1 g of the liquid phase into gas at the boiling point
        • 40.7 kJ/mol or 2260 J/g for H2O
  • Phase Diagrams
    • A pressure vs temperature graph for a single pure substance enclosed in a rigid container
    • Triple point - values of P and T where all three phases can exist in equilibrium
    • Critical point
      • Values of P and T where P is critical pressure and T is critical temperature
      • Critical pressure - minimum pressure necessary to have liquid at the critical temperature
      • Critical temperature - highest temperature at which the liquid phase can exist
    • Supercritical fluid
      • Occurs for a substance with P and T past its critical point
      • Strange properties
  • Solids
    • Amorphous vs. Crystalline
      • Amorphous solids have no pattern, generally formed by cooling rapidly
      • Crystalline solids have a crystal lattice - regular, repeating pattern or arrangement of particles
    • Type of crystalline solids - four types which are organized/classified by attractive force

Type
Force
Particle type
Properties
Ionic
Ionic bonds
Ions
Hard, brittle, poor thermal and electrical conductors, high melting points
Molecular
IMFs
Atoms/molecules
Soft, poor thermal and electrical conductors, low melting points
Metallic
Metallic bonds
Atoms (+ ions in a "sea" of electrons)
Soft to very hard, good thermal and electrical conductors, wide range of melting points
Covalent network
Covalent bonds
Atoms/molecules
Very hard, poor thermal and electrical conductors with the exception of diamond and graphite
  • Band Theory
    • Metallic bonding
    • Molecular Orbital Theory
      • When orbitals on isolated atoms interact, the electron waves add and subtract to produce new orbitals which encompass multiple nuclei
      • Two interacting atomic orbitals yield two new molecular orbitals, one higher in energy (anti-bonding) and one lower in energy (bonding)
      • The interaction of many sodium atom orbitals leads to a band of molecular orbitals
      • In metals, the s bands and p bands overlap, allowing electron movement, even when the s band is full
      • A large band gap (such as with non-metal atoms) is called a forbidden zone
      • The small band gap in the metalloids permits thermally excited electrons to jump into the higher band and then move
      • For metals, as temperature increases, resistance increases, whereas for metalloids, as temperature increases, resistance decreases

title: Chapter 15 Notes
description:
• Thermodynamics
    • Energy - the capacity to do work or transfer heat
    • System - the portion of the universe that we are focused on
    • Surroundings - the remainder of the universe
    • Matter and energy flow by system type (between system and surroundings)
      • Open - matter can flow
      • Closed - matter cannot flow
      • Adiabatic - energy cannot flow
      • Isolated - matter and energy cannot flow
      • Isothermal - no temperature change
    • State functions
      • Properties of a system which depend on its present state, not its history (ex: Pressure, Volume, Temperature)
      • Key state functions - E, H, S, G
        • E - Internal Energy
          • Sum of all the kinetic and potential energies of the matter in the system
          • /\ E = E f - E i = q + w
          • q - heat absorbed by system from surroundings
          • w - work done on system by surroundings
            • Can be pressure-volume or electrical
            • Units - P*V = L*kPa = J
            • The work done on a system at constant external pressure is w = -P ext * /\ V = -(/\ n)RT
        • H - Enthalpy
          • Heat content / total energy
          • H = E + P*V
          • Total energy = internal energy + energy it expended to create its space
          • /\ H = q p
          • The change in enthalpy is measured by the heat absorbed by the system under constant pressure
          • Determining /\ H
            1. Coffee cup calorimeter experiment
            2. Hess's law problems
            3. /\ H o f (heats of formation)
            4. Bond energies (estimate)
            5. Using other thermodynamic state functions (S, G)
          • if /\ H = H f - H i < 0 - exothermic (surroundings get warmer)
          • if /\ H > 0 - endothermic (cooling of surroundings)
          • Manipulations of /\ H
            1. When equations are added, the /\ H's are added
            2. When an equation is multiplied by a constant, the /\ H is also multiplied by that constant
            3. When an equation is reversed, the /\ H is reversed in sign
          • /\ H o f - standard heats of formation
            1. The standard heat of formation of any element in its standard state is zero
            2. The /\ H o f of any compount is the /\ H for the reaction in which 1 mole of the compound is formed from its constituent elements in their standard states (1 bar, 298.15 K)
          • Bond energies
            • The amount of energy required to break 1 mole of bonds of a gas phase covalent compound
            • Ex: CH4 (g) -> C (g) + 4H (g) /\ H = 4 * BE (C-H)
          • Calorimetry
            • 2 types of calorimetry
              1. Coffee-cup calorimeters
                • /\ H is heat absorbed at constant pressure
                • No gases
              2. Bomb calorimeters
                • /\ E is heat absorbed at constant volume
                • Can handle gases
            • The heat that is absorbed by the calorimeter itself is referred to as the heat capacity of the calorimeter and is generally given in kJ/degree C or J/degree C
        • S - Entropy
          • Predicting the spontaneity of reactions
          • Predicting the max work that can be done by a reaction
          • A reaction is said to be "spontaneous" if it can occur without outside help
          • Thermodynamic stability come from
            1. Lower energy
            2. Greater disorder - dispersal of matter and energy
          • 1877 Ludwig Boltzman
            • S = entropy -> disorder, chaos
            • S = k*ln(omega)
              • k - Boltzman's constant
              • omega - # of possible arrangements of system
          • /\ S universe > 0 - for all spontaneous changes
          • /\ S universe = /\ S system + /\ S surroundings
          • Changes in systems which increase entropy
            1. Increase in temperature
            2. Increase in volume
            3. Increase in # of particles
            4. Phase changes: s -> l -> g
            5. Increase in # of moles of gas
            6. Mixing of substances
          • Absolute Entropy
            • S 298 is the absolute entropy of a substance
            • Units of J/K or J/(K*mol)
            • Represents the entropy of 1 mol of the substance at 1 atm and 298 K
          • Qualitative prediction of the relative size of S 298 for different substances
            • Size/complexity - as molecular substances increase in size and complexity, S 298
            • For ionic substances, as charge density increases, S 298 decreases
          • /\ S rxn = sum(S 298 (products)) - sum(S 298 (reactants))
        • G - Gibbs Free Energy
          • J. Willard Gibbs
          • The energy available to do work
          • Definition - G = H - T*S
          • /\ G = /\ H - T*/\ S
            • If /\ G < 0 - spontaneous reaction, products are thermodynamically favored
            • If /\ G > 0 - non-spontaneous reaction, reactants are thermodynamically favored
            • If /\ G = 0 - equilibrium
          • How /\ G is determined
            1. /\ G = /\ H - T*/\ S
            2. Using /\ G of formation and /\ G = sum(/\ G (products)) - sum(/\ G (reactants))
            3. Hess's law with /\ G's
    • Laws
      • 0th law - Heat always flows from warmer to cooler
      • 1st law
        1. Energy is neither created or destroyed
        2. The energy of an isolated is constant
        3. The total energy of the universe is constant
      • 2nd law
        1. Entropy of the universe is constantly increasing
        2. /\ S >= q/T
      • 3rd law - the entropy (S) of a perfect crystal at absolute zero is zero
      • Hess's law
        • The enthalpy change for a reaction is the same whether it occurs in one step or in a series of steps
        • /\ H A -> C = /\ H A -> B + /\ H B -> C
        • /\ H = /\ H1 + /\ H2
    • Thermochemical equations - coefficients must be interpreted in moles
      1. 2H2 (g) + O2 (g) -> 2H2O + 585 kJ
      2. 2H2 (g) + O2 (g) -> 2H2O; /\ H = -585 kJ

title: Chapter 16 Notes
description:
• Kinetics
    • The study of reaction rates
      1. How to define and measure the rate of a reaction
      2. Factors which affect reaction rates
      3. What we can learn about the process of chemical reactions
    • Rate
      • Change in something / change in time
      • /\ something / /\ t
      • d something / d t
      • Definition
        • aA + bB -> cC + eE
        • -1/a * d [A]/d t = -1/b * d [B]/d t = 1/c * d [C]/d t = 1/e * d [E]/d t
      • How reaction rates measured
        • If /\ n != 0, can use pressure/temp
        • Change in pH for acid/base reactions
        • May be possible to use direct measurement of mass or volume of a particular reactant/product
        • Spectronic measurements for absorption of a particular wavelength of light
      • Gas and aqueous reactants/products change concentration with time, s,l phase substances do not
      • Factors that affect reaction rates
        1. Nature of reactants (s,l vs g,aq)
          • aA + bB -> products
          • If A or B is a liquid or a solid - heterogeneous phase reaction
          • The reaction rate is limited by the surface area available for the reactants to interact - rate is directly proportional to surface area
        2. Concentration
          • The relationship between the reactant concentrations and the rate of a reaction is quantified and expressed in the rate law
          • A rate law for a reaction has the form: rate = k*[A]^x*[B]^y*[C]^z
            • There is no direct relationship between a, b, c (the coefficients) and x, y, z (the exponents)
            • x, y, z usually are positive integers
          • "x" is the order of the reaction with respect to A - the overall order of the reaction is the sum of the exponents
          • Rate laws are often determined by the method of initial rates - a series of experiments run at the same temperature using different initial concentrations of the reactants
          • Integrated Rate Laws
            • First order
              • A -> products
              • rate = k*[A]
              • -d [A] / d t = k*[A]
              • integrate(-d [A] / d t, [A]0, [A]t) = -k*integrate(d t, 0, t)
              • ln [A]t - ln [A]0 = -k*t
              • [A]t = A[0]*e^(-k*t)
              • ln([A]t/[A]0) = -k*t
              • ln(1/2) = -kt 1/2
              • Half-life: t 1/2 = .693/k
              • ln [A]t is straight
            • Second order
              • 1/[A]t - 1/[A]0 = kt
              • Does not produce a constant half-life
        3. Temperature
          • Theory
            1. Collision theory - focus on the particles
              • In order for a reaction to occur, there must be a collision
              • Most collisions are ineffective (they do not result in a change)
              • In order for a collision to be effective
                • The collision must involve some minimum KE
                • The colliding particles must have the proper orientation
            2. Transition-state - energy
              • For reactants to become products, the reacting particles must pass through an intermediate high-energy state called the transition state or activated complex in which "old" bonds are breaking and new bonds are forming
              • The energy difference between the reacting particles and the activated complex is called the activation energy (Ea) for the reaction
          • Arrhenius Equation
            • k = A*e^(-Ea/(R*T))
              • k - rate constant
              • A - frequency factor (proportion of collisions at T which have proper orientation)
            • ln k = -Ea/R * 1/T + ln A
            • ln(k1/k2) = -Ea/R * (1/T1 - 1/T2)
        4. Catalysts
          • A catalyst is a substance which increases the rate of a chemical reaction but is neither a reactant nor a product in the chemical equation
          • The increase in rate is the result of the introduction of a new mechanism which has a lower Ea and/or an increased frequency of proper orientation (A)
          • 2 types
            • Homogeneous
              • Same phase as reactants
              • Usually gas or aqueous phase substances
              • Ex: enzymes
            • Heterogeneous
              • Different phase than reactants
              • Usually solids on which gas or aqueous phase reactants absorb
    • Reaction mechanisms
      • Key ideas
        1. Most reactions proceed by a series of elementary steps
        2. An elementary reaction is one that occurs as the result of a single collision
        3. A unimolecular elementary step is a single particle colliding and falling apart
        4. A bimolecuar elementary step is two particles colliding
        5. Trimolecular or 3-body collisions are extremely rare
        6. The rate law for an elementary reaction is determined by the coefficients of the reacting particles
          • Unimolecular - first
          • Bimolecular - second
        7. The slowest step in a mechanism is called the rate-determining step
        8. Substances (particles) which are created during the reaction, then used up, are called reaction intermediates

title: Chapter 18 Notes
description:
• Acid/Base Equilibrium
    • HA <-> H+ + A-
      • K a - ionization constant
      • If HA is strong, K a is very large
      • If HA is weak, K a is very small
    • Auto-ionization of water
      • 2H2O (l) <-> H3O+ (aq) + OH- (aq) or H2O (l) <-> H+ (aq) + OH- (aq)
      • K w = [H+]*[OH-] at 25 degrees C = 1.0*10^-14 = x^2
      • x = 1.0*10^-7
    • pH and pOH
      • p means "-log of"
      • pH = -log([H+]) = -log(1.0*10^-7) = 7.00
      • For pH's and any log number, the sig figs are the numbers after the decimal point
      • pOH = -log([OH-]) = -log(1.0*10^-7) = 7.00
    • pH scale
      • 7 is neutral
      • Lower pH means more acidic
      • Low bound is ~-2
      • Higher pH means more basic
      • High bound is ~16
      • pH + pOH = 14.00
    • Polyprotic Acids
      • HA - monoprotic acid
      • H2A - diprotic
      • H3A - triprotic
      • Each proton donation has its own equilibrium constant
  • Salts
    • Definitions
      • A salt is a compound formed by the reaction of an acid and a base
      • A salt is an ionic compound
    • Salts can be categorized based on the acid and base from which they are formed
      • Strong/strong - neutral solution
      • Strong/weak - basic solution
      • Weak/strong - acidic
      • Weak/weak - depends on the value of K (not covered)
    • CH3COO- + H2O <-> CH3COOH + OH-
      • Hydrolysis reaction
      • Kb = Kw/Ka
      • From this we get Kw=Ka*Kb
      • The weaker the acid, the stronger its conjugate base
    • Procedure
      1. Identify the substance dissolved as
        1. Acid
        2. Base
        3. Salt (with its category)
      2. If a salt, write the dissolving reaction
      3. For any ion from a weak acid/base, write the hydrolysis equilibrium and determine its K
      4. Make the equilibrium table

title: Chapter 17 Notes
description:
• Chemical Equilibrium
    • Chemical equilibrium occurs when a chemical reaction is proceeding at equal rate in both the forward and reverse direction
    • Equilibrium constants
      • Unitless quantities
      • K c
        • Concentration
        • Suppose a reaction has a 1 step mechanism, A + B -> C
        • rate forward = rate reverse
        • k f*[A]*[B] = k r*[C]
        • k f / k r = [C] / [A]*[B] = K c
        • For aA + bB -> cC + dD, K c = ([C]^c * [D]^d)/([A]^a * [B]^b)
        • This is called the equilibrium expression for a reaction
      • K p
        • Pressure
        • K p = (P(C)^c * P(D)^d) / (P(A)^a * P(B)^b)
        • P is partial pressure
      • Solids and liquids do not appear in equilibrium expressions
      • Information conveyed by the value of K
        1. If K is large (> 100), reaction is product favored, mostly products at equilibrium
        2. If K is small (< .01), the reaction is product favored, mostly reactants at equilibrium
        3. If K is intermediate (.01 < K < 100), significant amount of both products and reactants are present
      • The value of K depends only on temperature
      • Manipulation of K
        1. If the equation is reversed, the K is inverted
        2. If the equation is multiplied by a constant, the K is raised to that power
        3. If two or more equations are added, the K of the new equation is the product of the K's of the individual reactions
    • Le Chatelier's Principle
      • When any system at equilibrium is "stressed" (disturbed) the system will shift to reduce the stress
      • Stress
        1. Adding or removing a reactant or product
        2. Changing the volume
        3. Changing the temperature
      • Fake stress
        1. Adding or removing a non-reactant or non-product
        2. Addition of a catalyst
    • Reaction quotient
      • Q = ([C]^c * [D]^d) / ([A]^a * [B]^b)
      • No requirement that these concentrations are at equilibrium
      • If Q=K, the system is at equilibrium
      • If Q<K, the reaction is moving toward the reactants
      • If Q>K, the reaction is moving toward the products
    • /\ G o and K
      • /\ G = /\ G + RT*ln(Q)
      • At equilibrium, /\ G = 0 and Q = K
      • 0 = /\ G o + RT*ln(K)
      • /\ G o = RT*ln(K)
      • If reaction is aqueous, K c
      • If reaction is gaseous, K p

title: Chapter 20 Notes
description:
• Solubility Products
    • For a salt dissolving in water
      • AB <-> A+ + B-
      • K sp = [A+]*[B-]
      • Found in Appendix H
  • Formation of precipitates
    • Combining ions in a solution to form some solid salt
    • Will a precipitate form? - procedure
      1. Calculate the concentration of the relevant ions n the solution
      2. Use those concentrations to calculate Q
      3. Compare Q to K
        • If Q > K then precipitate formed
        • If Q < K then no precipitate formed
        • IF Q = K then at equilibrium
  • Voltaic Cells
    • Using a spontaneous redox reaction to generate electricity
    • Must physically separate the oxidation reaction from the reduction
    • Voltaic cells are composed of 2 half-cells which are separated by a barrier but connected by a salt bridge
    • Voltmeter - measures the tendency of electrons to flow (the electromotive force)
    • Each half-cell must contain both oxidized and reduced forms of a substance
    • For standard cells, the solutions are 1 M, any gases are at 1 atm, and temperature is 25 degrees C
    • Salt bridge is usually agar with KCl - provides electrical connection between the half-cells
  • E - standard reduction potential
  • Cell Notation
    • Anode -> cathode - follow the electrons
    • Cr|Cr+3||Au+3|Au
  • /\ G o = n*F*E o
    • n - integer number of electrons in balanced equation
    • F - 96485 C/mol e-

title: Chapter 19 Notes
description:
• Equilibrium of Buffers and Titrations
    • Buffers
      • Definitions
        • A solution which resists changes in pH from added acid or base is called a buffered solution
        • A solution which contains approximately equal (within a 10:1 ratio) concentrations of a weak acid or base and its conjugate
      • Two ways to construct a buffer
        • Add approximately equal amounts of a weak acid or base and a salt which contains the conjugate
        • Add approximately half as much strong acid or base to a solution of a weak base or acid
      • Henderson-Hasselbach
        • Acid form: pH = pKa + log([A-]/[HA])
        • Only used on buffer solutions
        • For any weak acid, pH = pKa +- 1
  • Titrations
    • A weak acid titrated with strong base
      • pH/eq calculations summary
        1. Before the addition of any base it is a weak acid equilibrium problem
        2. After the addition of some base, but prior to reaching equivalence, it is a buffer equilibrium problem
        3. When the equivalence point is reached, it is a hydrolysis equilibrium problem
        4. Past equivalence, it is just a strong base solution (no equilibrium)
  • Acid/base Indicators
    • A substance which displays a different color aqueous solution at low pH versus high pH
    • They are weak acids for which the acid form absorbs visible light differently than its conjugate
    • Indicators change color +-1 pH around their pKa

title: Chapter 12 Notes
description:
• Phases of Matter
    • Gases
      • Measurements on gases
        • Pressure
          • Symbol is P
          • Force/Area
          • N/m^2 - Pa, pascal
          • Non-SI
            • atm, Atmosphere
            • mm Hg / torr, millimeter Hg
            • 1 atm = 760 mm Hg = 760 torr = 101.325 kPa
        • Volume, v in L
        • Moles, n in mol
        • Temperature, T in Kelvins
      • Empirically derived Gas Laws
        • P1*V1 = P2*V2 - Boyle's Law
        • V1/n1 = V2/n2 - Avogadro's Law
        • V1/T1 = V2/T2 - Charles' Law
        • P1*V1/T2 = P2*V2/T2 - combined gas law
      • STP - standard temperature and pressure
      • Standard molar volume - 22.4 L/mol
      • Ideal Gas Law - P*V = n*R*T
      • Constant R
        • .08206 L*atm / mol*K
        • 8.314 L*kPa / mol*K or J*mol^-1*K^-1
        • 62.36 L*torr / mol*K
  • Dalton's Law
    • Gas mixtures
    • Pt = Pa + Pb + Pc ...
    • Pt = total pressure exerted by the mixture
    • Pa = partial pressure exerted by gas A
  • Mole fraction
    • XA  - the mole fraction of A
    • XA = nA / nt = mol A / total moles
  • Kinetic-Molecular Theory (KMT)
    • Ideal Gas Model
    • Rudolf Clausius - 1858
    • Postulates
      1. Gases are composed of tiny particles (atoms, molecules)
      2. These particles are in rapid, random, straight-line motion until collision with walls or other particles
      3. The particles have zero volume (i.e. the volume of the particles (particle volume) is so small compared to the gas volume that it is insignificant)
      4. The collisions of the particles with each other and the walls are perfectly elastic
      5. There are no attractive or repulsive forces between the particles
    • Maxwell-Boltzman additions
      1. The average KE of the particles is directly proportional to the absolute temperature (i.e. 1/2 * mv^2 = KT) - introduces K as Boltzman constant
      2. The distribution of the KE among the particles is random
    • Problems
      • High P, low T
      • Gases composed of large molecules with strong attractive forces
  • Effusion
    • Effusion is the movement of a gas through a small opening
    • Graham's Law of Effusion - the rate of effusion of any gas is inversely proportional to the square root of its molar mass - r1/r2 = sqrt(M2/M1)
      • 1/2 * m1 * v1^2 = 1/2 * m2 * v2^2
      • m1 * v1^2 = m2 * v2^2
      • v1^2/v2^2 = sqrt(m2/m1)
  • Van der Waal's Equation for Real Gases
    • (P + n^2/v^2 * a) * (V - n * b) = n * R * T
    • a and b are experimentally derived constants which are specific to the gas substance
    • a
      • P ideal = P measured + n^2/v^2 * a
      • a is proportional to the attractive forces between the particles
      • Stronger forces give a larger a
    • b
      • V ideal = V measured - n*b
      • b is proportional to particle size
      • Gases composed of larger particles and/or more particles have reduced space (volume) available for each particle to move within
  • Molecular Speeds
    • KE = KT
    • 1/2 * m * v^2 = KT
    • Root-mean square velocity is a means of quantifying the average speed of a gas particle

title: Wedding narration
description:
Oral exam : Sep 7 Thursday F day long period

Samedi dernier à 8h, je suis allée au mariage de Tom et Philip, mes amis de York. Ils se sont mariés à Carmel. Je suis arrivée à la maison de Tom à 7h45. j'allais vers le jardin quand la mère de Philip m'a envoyé un texto pour dire : "nous avons perdu le gâteau". Pas de problème. Je fais bien la cuisine. J'ai préparé un gâteau pour le mariage.

A 8h, la demoiselle d'honneur et le garçon d'honneur sont allés devant tous les invités. Le garçon d'honneur, Navid, avait les alliances. La demoiselle d'honneur, Sophie, portait un bouquet de fleurs pour Philip le marié #1. La cérémonie a fini à 8h30. Tom a embrassé Philip. J'ai applaudi et j
ai pleuré. La cérémonie a été très romantique.

Tom était très beau dans un short blanc de Rice. Il était content d'être avec toute la famille. Philip était pas très beau. Il portait un débardeur rose. Mais Philip était furieux parce qu'il a vu Tom avec Lucy!!

1. I can mention 8 different parts of a wedding while narrating a wedding story.

2. I can describe people physically and their emotions in the past.

3. I can place events in chronological order in the past.

4. I can say how I reacted to events. 

5. I can say one  action interrupted another. 

6. I can say that a couple got married.   


wedding vocabulary: le marié; la mariée; les alliances; le garçon d'honneur; la demoiselle d'honneur; le gâteau de marriage; le voyage des noces; la réception, les invités; la bague de fiançailles; à la mairie; se marier avec, être amoureux, robe de mariage; la lune de miel

physical descriptions: grand, a les yeux...; a les cheveux...; petit; maigre, gros, radieuse, beau, belle, etc.
emotions or moods: amoureux, content, heureux, heureuse, affolé; triste, mélancolique, jalouse, jaloux, fier (proud), anxieux, anxieuse,

I reacted: j'ai applaudi, j'ai crié; j'ai pleuré; j'ai ri; j'ai; je me suis endormi; je suis devenu paniqué;

place events in chronological order: d'abord, ensuite, après, et puis, finalement, enfin

one action interrupted another (action being interrupted) Le petit garçon marchait vers les mariés (interrupting action) quand il est tombé.

I can say a couple got married: Ils se sont mariés; Elles se sont mariées; Il s'est marié avec elle; Elle s'est mariée avec lui.

title: For analyzing a painting
description:
Voilà un tableau surréaliste célèbre du peintre X.  Présenter le tableau / Donner une catégorie au tableau / Identifier le peintre
C'est mon peintre autrichien favori. Donner une information sur le peintre. 
Vous pouvez voir ce tableau au Louvre à Paris. Mentionner où se trouve le tableau.
Nous voyons une femme avec son enfant au premier plan. A l'arrière plan, il y a deux scènes. Diviser le tableau en zones différents
A gauche, il y a une scène violente qui représente la persécution pendant l'Holocaust. A droite, il y a l'image d'un cimetière. Identifier les images, les objets, les personnage, les métaphores
Les scènes sont tragiques. Identifier l'ambiance.
Les couleurs sont chaudes et très sombres. La lumière faible vient de la droite et touche la figure de la femme. Décrire les couleurs et la lumière.
On examine les deux perles, c'est la femme qui pleure. Terminer avec une observation qui apprend ou surprend.

title: National Spanish Exam Level 3 Practice Questions
description:
2015 National Spanish Examination - Proficiency - Level 3

Reading Comprehension.

This section will measure your proficiency in reading Spanish and contains 14 multiple choice questions in increasing order of difficulty. You should work as far into the section as you can.

Each item is comprised of (1) a context in English, (2) an authentic reading in Spanish, and (3) a question in English. Each question is followed by four possible answers, only ONE of which is correct. Choose the ONE answer which best completes each statement. 

  1. Miguel sees the following article on a health website.

    Algunos alimentos que consumimos contribuyen a la formación de caries y a la formación de bacterias. Para prevenir esto es bueno evitar el excesivo consumo de los siguientes alimentos: frutas cítricas, caramelos masticables o duros, bebidas gaseosas, vino, café y té. Los alimentos que pueden prevenir o incluso revertir el daño de nuestros dientes son los siguientes: chicles sin azúcar, agua, lácteos como la leche y el queso, fresas y comidas altas en fibras. Ahora ya sabes qué alimentos dañan tus dientes y cuáles ayudan a revertir el daño. No tienes excusas para no cuidar tus dientes y mantenerlos saludables.


    What is the purpose of this text?
    It explains how bacteria can cause dental cavities.
    It describes when to eat certain foods during the day.
    It identifies ways to remove food from teeth without brushing.
    It lists foods that are both good and bad for dental health.


  1. The following notice is posted on a website that advertises homes and apartments for rent.

    Piso en el centro de Madrid. El piso tiene un ambiente agradable junto a los famosos bares de tapeo en la Plaza Mayor y la Puerta del Sol. Es muy grande y está completamente reformado. Además está bien comunicado con las estaciones de Metro. Cuenta con una gran cocina equipada con todos los electrodomésticos necesarios. Tiene dos baños y una habitación completamente amueblada con cama, armario, mesa de estudio y silla. Hay una terraza enorme. El precio que paga incluye Internet wi-fi, agua y limpieza semanal. Los gastos de electricidad y gas no están incluidos pero son de sólo 30 € al mes.


    What type of person would be interested in this posting?
    A single person who enjoys living in the countryside.
    Someone with a large family and several pets.
    A person who travels by subway often.
    Someone who doesn’t mind paying extra for expensive luxuries.


  1. A friend in Spain has sent you a link to a blog that contains this posting.

    La gran mayoría de los jóvenes pasamos gran parte de nuestro tiempo en las redes sociales. Esto es algo asociado a la necesidad de poder expresar nuestras opiniones, pensamientos y (o) comentarios por medio de textos o con simples imágenes asociadas con esta. Podemos interactuar con demás personas de otros lugares del mundo por medio de fotos, comentarios, por vídeo chat o simplemente chat (que significa charla). Los jóvenes del siglo 21 encontramos cierto tipo de diversión o entretenimiento en estas bien llamadas redes sociales (Facebook, Twitter, Myspace, YouTube, Badoo, etc…). Es por eso que este pasatiempo es uno de los mejores que existe en la actualidad para los jóvenes.


    What is the opinion of this author?
    Some social networking sites do not have appropriate names.
    Expressing one’s opinion on social media can have negative consequences.
    Spending time using social media is a great way for young people to spend their leisure time.
    The great majority of young people spend too much time using social media.


  1. Camila is studying to become a flight attendant and is reading examples of the different announcements that she will have to make when she is aboard the aircraft someday.

    El comandante y todos nosotros les damos las gracias por elegir este vuelo con destino a Madrid. La duración estimada del vuelo será de una hora y diez minutos. Por motivos de seguridad y para evitar interferencias con los instrumentos de vuelo, les recordamos que los teléfonos móviles deberán permanecer desconectados desde el cierre de puertas y hasta su apertura en el aeropuerto de destino. Favor de guardar todo su equipaje de mano en los compartimentos superiores o debajo del asiento delantero, dejando despejados el pasillo y las salidas de emergencia. Ahora abróchense el cinturón de seguridad, mantengan el respaldo de su asiento en posición vertical y su mesita plegada. Estamos a punto de despegar. Gracias por su atención y feliz vuelo.


    During which part of the trip would this announcement be made?
    At takeoff.
    At landing.
    During an emergency.
    During turbulence in the air.


  1. Juan Luis is conducting some genealogy research when he comes across this posting on a family history site originating in Argentina.

    La palabra genealogía proviene del griego, "genos" (raza) y "logos" (ciencia), y consiste en la enumeración de los antepasados de una persona. Es una de las ciencias auxiliares de la historia (1) que trata del origen y descendencia de las familias (o de un linaje) a través de una realidad documental y (2) que por medio del estudio de documentos fidedignos se ocupa en establecer el parentesco entre personas y familias y el origen, descendencia y alianzas de las mismas. La genealogía se nutre de diversas fuentes de información escritas, pero siempre se debe comenzar por la tradición.


    What statement best summarizes this posting?
    It explains the importance of oral tradition and legal documents in doing genealogical research.
    It describes why genealogy is of historical importance to society.
    It defines genealogy as a subcategory of history in which a person traces his/her lineage.
    It classifies the steps in researching one’s ancestry.


  1. While hiking through a park in Uruguay, you come across the following sign.

    Mantengamos limpio nuestro parque, bosque, playa, y así estaremos colaborando con la hermosa naturaleza que nos rodea, evitando con cada desperdicio que arrojamos destruir la ecología que tanto intentamos preservar. 


    What is the purpose of the sign?
    To explain what parts of the park are closed due to recent storm damage.
    To request that visitors respect the environment while using the park.
    To warn of the dangers that might be encountered while hiking in the park.
    To ask hikers to preserve the natural ecological balance by picking up after pets.


  1. Valentina is taking a cooking class and is assigned the following article in a culinary arts magazine.

    La quinua es un cereal muy antiguo endémica a las culturas andinas. Los españoles, desconociendo el poder nutritivo de la quinua y recelosos de su costado religioso, lo descartaron y reemplazaron por otros alimentos. Se cultiva desde hace más de cinco mil años en toda la región del altiplano andino en América del Sur a más de 3.000 metros de altura sobre el nivel del mar. Los antiguos incas la llamaban el Grano Madre y la veneraban como planta sagrada. Muchos estudios recientes dicen que el valor nutritivo de la quinua es sólo comparable con la leche materna, lo que la convierte en uno de los alimentos más completos y balanceados. Por eso la NASA la incluyó en los menús de los astronautas para los viajes espaciales de larga duración. Su aspecto es similar al cuscús y su sabor cercano al arroz integral.


    What example is given as evidence of quinoa’s nutritional value?
    That it is recommended for pregnant women.
    That Spanish conquerors likened it to brown rice.
    That the Incas used it as a holistic remedy.
    That astronauts use it in long space flights.


  1. Matilda sees this posting about vacation packages on her way into the grocery store.

    ¿Te gusta nadar y broncearte? ¿Te gusta pasar el día relajándote en la arena o jugando al volibol? Si te gustan estas actividades, ven a nuestra reunión para familiarizarte con la información de viajes que ofrecemos en la Oficina del Sol. Ofrecemos varios paquetes vacacionales de diferentes actividades. Tenemos paquetes para cualquier afición. También ofrecemos paquetes turísticos de muchos lugares. Si necesitas alejarte de la tensión del trabajo o de los estudios, ven para descubrir las vacaciones perfectas para ti.


    What does this advertisement offer to a prospective traveler?
    A price list of activities that are included in various vacation packages.
    A seminar about various travel packages.
    A comparison of the different tourist themes of different travel agencies.
    A description of the psychological benefits of taking a vacation.


  1. Chloe sees this entry posted on a news website.

    Paleontólogos mexicanos anunciaron el descubrimiento en el desierto del estado de Coahuila de 50 vértebras que se piensa son la cola de un dinosaurio. El Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia indicó que la cola mide cinco metros (16 pies) y parece ser la de un hadrosáurido. Aunque no es posible confirmar la especie, sería la primera cola completa de ese tipo hallada en México. La paleontóloga Felisa Aguilar dijo que descubrieron casi la mitad del dinosaurio, que medía unos 12 metros (36 pies) y que vivió hace unos 72 millones de años. La excavación duró 20 días en la municipalidad de General Cepeda en el estado norteño, fronterizo con Estados Unidos. Los paleontólogos, que trabajaron en conjunto con la Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, hallaron además huesos de la cadera.


    What is the main point of the article?
    That dinosaur bones cannot last for more than 72 million years.
    That paleontologists identified a find in Mexico as a hadrosaur.
    That dinosaurs in Mexico are thought to have had very long tails.
    That archaeologists don’t usually dig in the Mexican desert.


  1. You have received this offer in the mail from a national cell phone company.

    Escribe tu código postal abajo y obtén 500 minutos a toda hora. Si te inscribes ahora, además recibirás llamadas ilimitadas, así como minutos de noche y fin de semana. El pago será sólo de $39.99 mensual con un contrato nuevo de 2 años.


    According to this advertisement, what is NOT included in this monthly package?
    Unlimited weekend calls.
    Unlimited text messages.
    500 anytime minutes.
    Unlimited nighttime calls.


  1. Rodrigo is browsing a technology website and comes across the following excerpt.

    Aunque las redes inalámbricas para conectarse a Internet son comunes en la mayoría de las ciudades del planeta, existen lugares extraños en los que se puede encontrar conexiones WiFi. Por ejemplo, un cementerio en Kentucky puede ser el único en el mundo en ofrecer conexión WiFi. El servicio fue establecido para ayudar a los visitantes con sus investigaciones genealógicas. Como otro ejemplo, una empresa de telefonía sueca instaló puntos de acceso a Internet WiFi a lo largo de la montaña más alta de la Tierra: el monte Everest. También, los primeros turistas espaciales que viajen con la compañía Virgin Galactic pueden sumar a la experiencia de la gravedad cero, la de navegar por Internet desde sus naves espaciales.


    What is the main point of the article?
    That it is possible to use wireless Internet all over the world.
    That Virgin Galactic intends to provide tours to outer space.
    That WiFi access is available in some very unusual and unexpected places.
    That Mount Everest is the only mountain in the world with WiFi.


  1. Megan sees this article in the entertainment section of an online magazine.

    La palabra “paparazzi” surge de una deformación de “pappataci”, palabra que en el idioma italiano se utiliza generalmente para designar a un grupo de insectos zumbadores tales como la mosca o los jejenes, los cuales son temidos por su picadura. Por analogía, los italianos la aplicaron a los fotógrafos, quienes solos o en enjambre acechan a diario a los ricos y famosos del mundo entero para obtener una imagen de su vida privada.


    According to the article, where does the word “paparazzi” come from?
    From a corrupt form of a word that means buzzing insects.
    From an Italian expression that refers to the sting of a bee.
    From a word that is usually used to describe people who snoop or pry.
    From an Italian word for predator of the rich and famous.


  1. Juanita reads this article in a cooking magazine while looking for an interesting recipe.

    Desde los albores de la cocina, nacieron las especias, las hierbas y los condimentos y, desde entonces, han acompañado todo platillo preparado por la especie humana. Durante mucho tiempo, algunos condimentos, como por ejemplo la sal, fueron los únicos recursos de los que se disponía para la conservación de los alimentos. También han sido utilizadas para dar sabor y color a los alimentos, pero aparte de sus usos culinarios la humanidad ha utilizado hierbas, especias y condimentos muy diversos para numerosos fines. Desde tiempos muy remotos varias culturas han utilizado hierbas para elaborar infusiones mitigadoras de dolores e incluso para la preparación de pociones mágicas por sus propiedades curativas. De todos modos, se destaca más el uso gastronómico--para dar sabor a los alimentos.


    According to this article, which is the most common use of herbs and spices?
    To preserve food.
    To add color to foods.
    To add flavor to foods.
    To cure the sick.


  1. While browsing a website originating in the Dominican Republic, you come across this text about sugar cane.

    La caña es originaria de Nueva Guinea, de donde pasó a la India y de allí a China. Con la expansión musulmana, los árabes la introdujeron por el Mediterráneo hasta la Península Ibérica, de donde pasó a las islas atlánticas próximas (Azores, Madeira, Canarias). Cristóbal Colón introdujo a La Española la caña de azúcar durante su segundo viaje en 1493, pero no fue hasta el año 1501, después de varios intentos, cuando se logró prender la planta que procedía de las Islas Canarias. Desde La Española fue extendida hacia Cuba, Puerto Rico y toda América, convirtiéndose el continente americano en el mayor productor de azúcar de caña del mundo.


    According to the text, what is the origin of the sugar cane which finally took root in Hispaniola?
    Cuba.
    New Guinea.
    The Canary Islands.
    The Iberian Peninsula.
